NewsDetail.Title: Questions, Problems, & Cases: Learning How to Frame Collaboration Activities to Reach Our Objectives
NewsDetail.Abstract: To become better at the art of developing good questions and problems, a Learning Community for instructors has been established this semester.
NewsDetail.Author: Devan barker
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Good questions and problems are critical to engaging students in our courses.  If we can draw upon students' curiosity and their instinctive nature to solve problems learning becomes exciting.  Yet coming up with the good questions is difficult.  It is not easy to find problems that are both relevant to students and reach your learning objectives.

 

 To become better at the art of developing good questions and problems, a Learning Community for instructors has been established this semester.  This community allows faculty to share thoughts and glean ideas from colleagues on the topic.  The group meets weekly for an hour on Tuesday afternoons.   

 

Interested faculty members are invited to participate in this group which is facilitated by Bill Riggins.  Each week a foundation principle is drawn from Ken Bain's book, "What the Best College Teachers Do" as a springboard to start the discussion.  The conversation follows the interests of the participants and answers their questions such as:  

 

1.       What do we know about intriguing questions, problems, or cases that would help us create a "natural critical learning environment?"

 

2.       How do questions, problems, or cases help in engaging students in some higher order intellectual activity?

 

3.       How could we use questions, problems or cases to assist in helping students construct their own understanding?

 

4.       How could we use questions, problems, or cases to help students develop their own questions?

 

5.       What is a "natural critical learning environment?"

 

Many have found the collegial conversation and the weekly format of Learning Communities to be a good fit for their professional development.  Matt Alba, who participated last year explained that the Learning Community gave him "the opportunity to share challenges, successes, new ideas and progress and in a friendly, small-group format with colleagues from around the university." He further noted that it was more than a support group. "[It] gave us a chance not to commiserate, but to put our heads together to come up with practical solutions."

 

To participate in the Learning Community contact Bill Riggins or simply come to the group's meeting which are held on Tuesday afternoons at 12:45 in Clarke 112.  A Learning Community that discusses Assessment is also meeting weekly this semester.  For more information about this group contact Richard Pieper.
